brief_description: This is a double-blind, multi-center, placebo controlled, Phase II study designed to assess biologic effects of 12 weeks of vitamin D3 supplementation on patients with well-controlled stable systemic lupus erythematosus who have low serum levels of 25-OH vitamin D and an IFN alpha signature.
brief_title: Vitamin D3 in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (ALE02)
description: This is a double-blind, multi-center, placebo controlled, Phase II study designed to assess biologic effects of 12 weeks of vitamin D3 supplementation on patients with well-controlled stable systemic lupus erythematosus who have low serum levels of 25-OH vitamin D and an IFN alpha signature.
endpoints: The primary safety endpoint of this study is to measure the proportion of subjects in each study arm experiencing any adverse event > Grade 3 (NCI-CTCAE) over the duration of follow-up. This study is not designed to assess efficacy, but the impact of vitamin D repletion on clinical
hypothesis: The proportion of subjects experiencing an IFN alpha signature response at Week 12 will be greater in the group supplemented with vitamin D3 compared to the group treated with placebo. A positive IFN alpha signature response for an individual is defined as a 50% decrease in expression of one IFN alpha responsive gene or a 25% decrease of two IFN alpha responsive genes, and no increase (of at least 25%) of the other IFN alpha inducible genes being assayed.
objectives: The primary objective of this study is to explore the impact of vitamin D3 supplementation on the expression of an IFNalpha signature
official_title: ALE02 - Effect of Vitamin D3 on the IFN alpha Signature in Patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
